qas.question: What is composed of two rotations?
What rotation can a rotation be reversed by?
What essential condition must be met for a subset of a group to be a subgroup?
What is defined when moving in the opposite direction?
270 for 180 is an example of what kind of rotation?
subgroup R is made up of the inverse and what?
What is unimportant for understanding the group as a whole?
Knowing the group as a whole is important for understanding what?

context: In the example above, the <b5_0>identity<b5_0/> and the rotations constitute a subgroup R = {id, r1, r2, r3}, highlighted in red in the group table above: any two rotations composed are still <a0_0>a rotation<a0_0/>, and a rotation can be undone by (i.e. is <a1_0>inverse<a1_0/> to) the <b4_0>complementary<b4_0/> rotations 270° for 90°, 180° for 180°, and 90° for 270° (note that <b3_0>rotation<b3_0/> in the opposite direction is not defined). <a2_0>The subgroup test<a2_0/> is a necessary and sufficient condition for a subset H of a group G to be a subgroup: it is sufficient to check that g−1h ∈ H for all elements g, h ∈ H. Knowing the <b6_0>subgroups<b6_0/> is important in understanding <b7_0>the group as a whole<b7_0/>.d[›]
